Award.AwardTitle: ABI Development: Association of protein helices in membranes: from physics to biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor to develop a new computational method, associated web server, and a database for structural studies of transmembrane (TM) alpha-helical complexes. Motivated by the lack of systematic analysis of single-spanning (bitopic) proteins, the most abundant class of membrane proteins, we propose to create web resources for modeling alpha-helix association in membranes and to apply these resources to study bitopic proteins from six organisms representing all kingdoms of life. These proteins frequently self-associate via TM alpha-helices to perform their functions as receptors, channels, auxiliary transport proteins, enzymes, structure/adhesion proteins, or regulators. A proposed physics-based method will implement our anisotropic solvent model of the lipid bilayer, template-driven helix docking, and new interatomic potentials that reproduce free energy of helix association in membranes. The new web tool, TMDOCK, will calculate three-dimensional structures and stabilities of TM helices, their dimers, and symmetric homo-oligomers. The Membranome database (http://membranome.org) will organize the obtained models and provide structural classification, intracellular localization, topology, domain organization, and functional annotation of proteins. Analysis of TM helical oligomers will be performed to reveal evolutionary trends in self-association of helices in different functional categories of bitopic proteins.

The project will have a broad impact for researchers studying membrane-active peptides and proteins by providing the first easy-to-use web server that is practical for high-throughput modeling of helix complexes in membranes. The availability of this tool to the scientific community will accelerate structural and functional studies of membrane proteins, facilitate understanding of mechanisms of pore and channel formation by antimicrobial peptides and polypeptide toxins, enable modeling of bihelical TM proteins, identify folding intermediates of polytopic proteins, and assist in de-novo design of self-associating peptides with potential use in pharmacology and bio-nanotechnology. The Membranome database will be an important resource with multiple purposes ranging from education to cutting edge academic research. It will consolidate our knowledge on bitopic proteins and facilitate comparative analysis of these proteins. Rich graphics, interactive visualization tools and tangible molecular models based on protein structures from the database will provide a valuable educational resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins with a single alpha-helix spanning cellular membranes represent the most abundant and functionally diverse class of membrane proteins. They participate in numerous biological processes, including cell adhesion, cell-cell communication, regulation of signaling, transport and metabolism, immune response, cell differentiation, development, and death. It has been suggested that single-spanning membrane proteins, which recruit domains from soluble proteins and participate in an expanded intercellular communication network, are likely the key players in metazoan evolution. To perform their functions as receptors, channels, or regulators, these proteins associate with each other or join other membrane proteins in large molecular machines. However, high structural heterogeneity and instability of protein assemblies in membranes impede their experimental study. Therefore, despite functional importance of these proteins, our understanding of structure, interactions, and evolution of this thriving protein class is still very limited.

In this project, we developed a set of computational methods and a database for modeling and systematic analysis of single-spanning membrane proteins. New methods were implemented into an easy-to-use web server, TMDOCK, for structural modeling of individual proteins and their complexes in the lipid environment. Unlike molecular dynamics simulations, the new computational tool not only correctly reproduces experimental structures, but is more efficient and practical for large-scale structural modeling of complexes formed by transmembrane alpha-helices. TMDOCK will accelerate structural studies of membrane proteins and may have a transformative effect on the fields of structural biology, biophysics, and bioengineering, as it allows users of different expertise to promptly obtain all-atom three-dimensional models of alpha-helical dimers in membrane and evaluate their energetics. This web tool is also beneficial for de novo design of self-associating peptides with potential use in pharmacology and bio-nanotechnology. Application of these new methods have helped us in collaboration with other researchers to understand the mechanism of action of the antimicrobial peptide bactenecin in fighting antibiotic-resistant bacteria that cause tropical diseases, to propose the structure of pore-forming pentamers of the antibacterial peptide, gramicidin A, and to model functional complexes of several cytochrome P450s participating in metabolism of drugs and other xenobiotics.

The Membranome database was created to collect and systematize structural and functional data on more than 6,000 single-spanning membrane proteins from representatives of six kingdoms of life. The database consolidates our knowledge of these proteins and facilitates their evolutionary and functional analysis. Comparative analysis of proteins from six organisms demonstrates a significant expansion and diversification of these proteins during biological evolution from bacteria to eukaryotic organisms, and from unicellular to multicellular organisms. It also shows the structural adaptation of proteins to different types of biological membranes and provides the way to identify proteins targeting different cells and organelles, which can be used for protein engineering. The database and a new web tool also represent valuable educational resources. Participation of undergraduate students in database and server development and maintenance contributed to their professional training. Tangible molecular models based on protein structures from the database were used in a biology classroom to advance 3D literacy of Detroit Central High School students.
